plants.description: A fragrant culinary herb commonly used in cooking. It has mild medicinal properties but is mainly grown for flavor.
plants.morphology: A small leafy plant growing 30-60 cm tall. Leaves are smooth, bright green, soft, and oval-shaped with a pleasant smell.
plants.differentiation: Unlike Tulsi, sweet basil leaves are smooth and have a mild sweet aroma instead of a strong clove-like smell.
plants.uses: Used in cooking, helps mild digestion problems, reduces gas and bloating, and may help with mild headaches.
plants.preparationText: Boil 5-7 fresh leaves in water for 3-4 minutes and drink as light herbal tea.
plants.adverseEffects: Generally safe in food amounts. Very large amounts may affect blood clotting.
plants.contraindications: People taking blood-thinning medicines should avoid large medicinal use.

plants.description: A powerful medicinal tree widely used in rural India for skin diseases, infections, and oral health.
plants.morphology: A medium to large tree with long compound leaves made of many small pointed leaflets. Leaves taste very bitter.
plants.differentiation: Recognized by its strong bitterness and small white fragrant flowers.
plants.uses: Used for skin infections, wounds, pimples, itching, dandruff, and as natural insect repellent. Neem twigs are used for brushing teeth.
plants.preparationText: Crush fresh leaves into paste and apply on affected skin. For bathing, boil leaves in water and use that water.
plants.adverseEffects: Neem oil can be dangerous if swallowed, especially for children.
plants.contraindications: Avoid internal use during pregnancy and for small children.

plants.description: A thick succulent plant known for the cooling gel inside its leaves.
plants.morphology: Short stem plant with thick, fleshy green leaves having small teeth on the edges.
plants.differentiation: When cut open, clear slippery gel comes out from inside the leaf.
plants.uses: Used for burns, sunburn, minor wounds, skin dryness, and hair care. Helps cool the skin.
plants.preparationText: Cut a mature leaf, remove outer green skin carefully, and apply clear gel directly on skin.
plants.adverseEffects: The yellow latex under the skin can cause stomach pain and diarrhea if eaten.
plants.contraindications: People with stomach problems should not consume aloe latex.

plants.description: A sacred and medicinal plant widely used in Ayurveda for cough, cold, and immunity.
plants.morphology: A small plant 30-60 cm tall with hairy stems and slightly rough leaves that have a strong smell.
plants.differentiation: Leaves are slightly hairy and smell strong and spicy like clove.
plants.uses: Used for cough, cold, fever, immunity boosting, stress reduction, and respiratory health.
plants.preparationText: Boil 5-10 fresh leaves in one cup of water for 5 minutes and drink warm.
plants.adverseEffects: Excess use may lower blood sugar too much.
plants.contraindications: Pregnant women should consult doctor before regular medicinal use.
